newsitem.title: BOSNIA: FEATURE - Refugees wonder if elections will carry them home.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Refugees wonder if elections will carry them home.

text.p: When Fatima Husejnovic votes in Bosnia's post-war elections on September 14, she will be carrying a faded postcard in her purse, the only memento of a decent life long gone.
The postcard shows a row of drab apartment blocks in an industrial town called Srebrenica.
For Husejnovic, it evokes a peaceful, prosperous time in old Yugoslavia, before the world associated Srebrenica with terrified refugees and brutal war crimes.
"That's our home," she said proudly, pointing to a modest, two-storey house in the picture. "We lived well. Everyone had at least one car."
As Husejnovic marks her absentee ballot on September 14, she will do so hoping the election will bring her back to Srebrenica and the harmonious life she knew before the war.
Conquering Bosnian Serb forces expelled Husejnovic and other Moslem women and children from Srebrenica last July. A Serb soldier took away her husband before he could board her bus.
"That was the last time I saw him."
The Dayton peace treaty promised Husenjovic and two million other refugees from Bosnia the right to return to their homes before voting in "free and fair" elections.
Instead, nationalist authorities across Bosnia have blocked Moselm, Serb and Croat refugees from coming back, sealing the results of ethnic cleansing and military conquest.
Comprising about half the electorate, the refugees represent a crucial voting bloc for the nationalist parties vying for power.
Robbed of their homes and their dignity, the 1.7 million displaced and refugees who registered to vote are vulnerable to manipulation and blackmail, both psychological and financial.
"For a refugee who has nothing, it means everything when the party offers him a flat or a job," said a local aid worker in the northeastern city of Tuzla where many Srebrenica refugees ended up.
The architects of Dayton envisaged civilians moving back to their pre-war homes, electing authorites to rule over restored multi-ethnic communities.
But ethnic leaders treat the refugees like chips in an electoral board game, stacking the odds in their own favour.
Before the war, Srebrenica, like many municipalities in eastern Bosnia, had a Moslem majority.
Serb authorities have moved thousands of Serbs into an ethnically "cleansed" Srebrenica in a bid to keep out the original residents.
To tip the electoral balance, refugees who live in neighbouring Serbia have been registered to vote in Srebrenica in what human rights workers call a calculated campaign of "ethnic engineering".
The battle for control of Srebrenica, in which refugees are mere pawns, reflects a political struggle being waged in dozens of towns across the country.
Prevented from coming home, Husejnovic and other Srebrenica survivors have registered to vote by absentee ballot.
International organisers say the outcome in Srebrenica will be close when voters select cantonal representatives during the September general election and municipal authorities later.
Depending on how many refugees rival ethnic parties can muster, the poll could elect Moslem authorities who could not safely enter the town.
No one knows how such an impasse would be solved, but the refugees fear powerful men will once again decide their fate.
Srebrenica refugees say no one from the Moslem-led government or the international community has even explained the election rules to them or how they will go back home.
Feeling abandoned, Husejnovic has tried to organise the women of Srebrenica, demanding they be allowed to return and learn the truth about their missing loved ones.
She has no office for the organisation and has spent her own money to buy notebooks.
Her attempts to rally the Srebrenica women follow a past littered with broken promises.
She remembers when her town turned into a "prison" teeming with refugees and cut off from food aid.
She remembers French U.N. peackeeping force General Philippe Morillon speaking to the starving, besieged Moslems in the enclave, "Don't be afraid, I will stay with you."

She remembers when the Moslem officers commanding Srebrenica's defences were called back to Sarajevo for "training". Five days later, the Bosnian Serb army launched its assault on what the U.N. had declared a "safe area".
Despite everything, she clings to the belief that the elections will somehow bring her closer to returning home. "We hope we can go back. We have to hope."
Human rights workers say refugees like Husejnovic, who are more interested in co-existence than territorial conquest, hold the key to any lasting peace and reconciliation in Bosnia.
They fear that if nationalist parties emerge victorious as widely predicted, the elections will prevent Husejnovic from ever returning home.
